noteParagraph.text: As far as possible, an invention is classified primarily according to constructional features; classification according to particular kinds of aircraft is normally regarded as being of secondary importance, except in cases where this is understood to be the characteristic feature.

titlePart.text: Constructional features common to fuselages, wings, stabilising surfaces, and the like
titlePart.entryReference: aerodynamical features common to fuselages, wings, stabilising surfaces, and the like

titlePart.text: Construction or attachment of skin panels

titlePart.entryReference: fairings movable in conjunction with undercarriage elements

titlePart.text: specially adapted for mounting power plant
Other structures integral with fuselages to facilitate loading
Steps mounted on, and retractable within, fuselages
Attaching the wing or tail units or stabilising surfaces
Parts of fuselage relatively movable to improve pilots view
Parts of fuselage relatively movable to reduce overall dimensions of aircraft
Severable or jettisonable parts of fuselage facilitating emergency escape
adapted to receive aerials or radomes
Constructions adapted to reduce effects of aerodynamic or other external heating

titlePart.entryReference: layered products or sandwich constructions in general

titlePart.text: Construction, shape, or attachment of separate skins, e.g. panels
Leading or trailing edges attached to primary structures, e.g. forming fixed slots
specially adapted for mounting power plant

titlePart.entryReference: other aircraft fuel tanks or fuel systems

titlePart.text: Structures adapted to reduce effects of aerodynamic or other external heating
Adjustment of complete wings or parts thereof
by relatively-movable parts of wing structures
by leading or trailing edge flaps
Folding or collapsing to reduce overall dimensions of aircraft
mounted on, or supported by, wings
for retraction against or within fuselage or nacelle
Structures or fairings not otherwise provided for
Adjustable control surfaces or members, e.g. rudders
with two or more independent movements
one surface adjusted by movement of another, e.g. servo tabs
titlePart.entryReference: adjusting surfaces of different type or function

titlePart.text: surfaces of different type or function being simultaneously adjusted
at the rear of the wing
at the front of the wing
by flaps at both the front and rear of the wing operating in unison
collapsing or retracting against or within other surfaces or other members
the members being fuselages or nacelles
Features common to propellers and rotors for rotorcraft
Arrangements of, or constructional features peculiar to, multiple propellers
Units of two or more coaxial propellers
Control systems or transmitting systems for actuating flying-control surfaces, lift-increasing flaps, air brakes, or spoilers

titlePart.entryReference: locking in position to suit individual persons

titlePart.text: actuated automatically, e.g. responsive to gust detectors
without power amplification or where power amplification is irrelevant
using cable, chain, or rod mechanisms
with automatic return to inoperative position
characterised by the fluid being gaseous
Attitude, flight direction, or altitude control by jet reaction
titlePart.entryReference: details of jet-engine plants, e.g. of nozzles or jet pipes,

titlePart.text: the jets being other than main propulsion jets
Aircraft stabilisation not otherwise provided for
Aircraft control not otherwise provided for
Influencing air-flow over aircraft surfaces, not otherwise provided for
Influencing air-flow over aircraft surfaces by affecting boundary-layer flow
by use of slot, ducts, porous areas, or the like
using other surface properties, e.g. roughness
Influencing air-flow over aircraft surfaces, not otherwise provided for
by means of rotating members of cylindrical or similar form
Fairings movable in conjunction with undercarriage elements
characterised by elements which contact the ground or similar surface
Arrangements or adaptations of wheels, tyres, or axles in general
the elements being rotated before touch-down
Brake regulators for preventing skidding or aircraft somersaulting

titlePart.entryReference: steering devices applicable to land vehicles

titlePart.text: Arrangements or adaptations of shock-absorbers or springs
Combinations of different kinds of ground or like engaging elements

titlePart.entryReference: arresting gear, e.g. on aircraft carriers

titlePart.text: Aircraft kinds and components not otherwise provided for
Direct drive between power plant and rotor hub
Drive of rotors by means, e.g. propellers, mounted on rotor blades
Rotorcraft characterised by having shrouded rotors, e.g. flying platforms
Compound rotorcraft, i.e. aircraft using in flight the features of both aeroplane and rotorcraft
with rotor blades fixed in flight to act as lifting surfaces
characterised by provision of fixed wings
with forward-propulsion propellers pivotable to act as lifting rotors
with provision for reducing drag of inoperative rotor

titlePart.entryReference: features common to rotors and propellers

titlePart.text: with individually articulated blades, i.e. with flapping or drag hinges
with flapping hinge or universal joint, common to the blades
Blades foldable to facilitate stowage of aircraft
Tilting of rotor bodily relative to fuselage
Mechanisms for controlling blade adjustment or movement relative to rotor head, e.g. lag-lead movement
characterised by the control initiating means, e.g. manually actuated
automatic or condition responsive, e.g. responsive to rotor speed, torque or thrust
Transmitting means, e.g. interrelated with initiating means or means acting on blades
including swash plate, spider or cam mechanisms
including rotating masses or servo rotors
specially for controlling lag-lead movements of blades
using fluid pressure, e.g. having fluid power amplification
using electrical energy, e.g. having electrical power amplification
in association with pitch adjustment of blades of anti-torque rotor
for differential adjustment of blade pitch between two or more lifting rotors
characterised by the provision of an auxiliary rotor or fluid-jet device for counter-balancing lifting-rotor torque or changing direction of rotorcraft
Aircraft capable of landing or taking-off vertically
titlePart.entryReference: attitude, flight direction, or altitude control by jet reaction
details of jet-engine plants, e.g. of nozzles or jet pipes,

titlePart.text: having its flight directional axis vertical when grounded

titlePart.entryReference: vehicles capable of travelling in or on different media

titlePart.text: Flying units formed by separate aircraft
having multiple fuselages or tail booms
